top_comment.author: Jessie Carty

comments.text:
I'm a student preparing for engineering, Vedic Calculations allow me to 
calculate faster than other students, so I can attempt more questions in an 
exam and save time for others. 

:) As I said, it's a tool, use where you see fit.
comments.author: Ayush Singh

comments.text:
Interesting. I never thought of differentiating between the term math and 
calculation, but my studies focused on writing and literature so I'm just 
coming back to thinking about math and how to teach it now. You have me 
thinking :)
comments.author: Jessie Carty

comments.text:
I'd have to rephrase myself a bit. Vedic mathematics is actually more of 
calculation than mathematics.

In the grand scheme of learning mathematics there are various concepts, so 
it might not be so useful in learning them at the very least. But in the 
application of those concepts, somewhere or the other numbers and 
respective operations arrive. And that's where this kicks in. It's just a 
tool to calculate not learn math (and usually kids fear heavy calculations, 
that's what it makes easy). 

So to sum it up, it can be useful where-ever there is calculation to reach 
the result faster and with lesser effort, other than that vedic mathematics 
isn't mathematics but calculation.
comments.author: Ayush Singh

Thse sutras are good, but personally I prefer the Egyptian binary system.  
It might be slower and a lot more laborious, but in a sense it is simpler 
because it involves nothing other than pure addition.  You just add the 
last number to itself, and keep iterating.﻿

comments.author: MrBum

top_comment.text:
Vedic maths is very 'in vogue' ATM. The Great Courses has a lecture series 
by Arthur Benjamin, the 'Mathemagician'.

As a maths teacher of many years, IMO this is the wrong way to teach 
arithmetic. Multiplication, for example, should be taught as being 
equivalent to addition. This promotes comprehension as opposed to the Vedic 
technique, which is nothing more than a series of parlour tricks.

I can't see the benefit, in the modern world, of promoting these techniques 
over using a calculator. They seem very impressive at first but are nothing 
more than a series of steps to follow if you don't understand what you are 
trying to do!﻿
top_comment.author: Noel Johansen-Berg

comments.text:
+Noel Johansen-Berg There is a practical limit to do maths by raw 
calculation. We tend to use a lot of memorization to help us with more 
difficult operations. The multiplication table for example is a basic 
element we use by memory to operate with real numbers. Having to perform 
raw addition is not really productive in this case but can be useful in 
other cases where huge numbers can be broken down into smaller pieces. If 
you've read Arthur's book on mental mathematics, you'd know that he use a 
lot of these 'parlour tricks' on top of his method and even devotes a 
section of his book on memory retention using mnemonics. 

I guess what I'm saying is that no comprehension is really lost by these 
methods. Think of it as toppings on an apple 3.14
comments.author: Wallace “Felixine” Goromchevna the 6th

comments.text:

answer is the same.
